docs.lead_paragraph: Prescribing drugs for conditions that they cannot actually cure isn’t just a benign gesture. It can cause real harm, in several ways.

headline.main: On an Antibiotic? You May Be Getting Only a False Sense of Security

docs.snippet: Prescribing drugs for conditions that they cannot actually cure isn’t just a benign gesture. It can cause real harm, in several ways.

docs.lead_paragraph: A young woman complaining of abdominal pain and nausea who had traveled to Africa arrived at a Long Island hospital fearful that she had contracted Ebola. She did not have the virus, but the pregnancy test was positive.

headline.main: U.S. Hospitals Gird for Ebola Panic as Flu Season Looms
headline.print_headline: U.S. Hospitals Gird for Ebola Panic as Flu Season Looms

docs.snippet: A young woman complaining of abdominal pain and nausea who had traveled to Africa arrived at a Long Island hospital fearful that she had contracted Ebola. She did not have the virus, but the pregnancy test was positive.

docs.lead_paragraph: It would be very hard to contain Ebola in a system that can't handle routine medical problems.
docs.snippet: It would be very hard to contain Ebola in a system that can't handle routine medical problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: Looking back, the mistakes are easy to see: Waiting too long, spending too little, relying on the wrong people, thinking small when they needed to think big. Many people, governments and agencies share the blame for failing to contain Ebola when it emerged in West Africa.

headline.main: Mission Unaccomplished: Containing Ebola in Africa
headline.print_headline: Mission Unaccomplished: Containing Ebola in Africa

docs.snippet: Looking back, the mistakes are easy to see: Waiting too long, spending too little, relying on the wrong people, thinking small when they needed to think big. Many people, governments and agencies share the blame for failing to contain Ebola when it...

docs.lead_paragraph: Health specialists said a travel ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations that are barely able to cope with the Ebola outbreak.

headline.main: Experts Oppose Ebola Travel Ban, Saying It Would Cut Off Worst-Hit Countries
headline.print_headline: Experts Oppose Travel Ban, Saying It Would Cut Off Worst-Hit Countries

docs.abstract: Public health officials say a travel ban on people coming from the three West African nations struggling with Ebola virus outbreak would be ineffective and difficult to carry out and would not entirely prevent people in Ebola-hit countries from entering the United States; health specialists say, that ultimately, a ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations already barely able to cope with virus.
docs.snippet: Health specialists said a travel ban would do more harm than good because it would isolate impoverished nations that are barely able to cope with the Ebola outbreak.

docs.lead_paragraph: The appointment of Ron Klain, a White House veteran, spoke of the seriousness of the situation for the administration, which hoped to put the management of the crisis back on track.

headline.main: Obama Names Democratic Operative to Coordinate Ebola Response
headline.print_headline: Obama Names Democratic Operative to Coordinate Ebola Response

docs.abstract: President Obama names trusted political adviser Ron Klain to take over government’s response to deadly Ebola virus, as health officials in two states work to track a growing list of people who may have been exposed because of missteps in quarantine and containment; appointment speaks to seriousness of the situation for the administration, which is eager to put the management of the crisis back on track.
docs.snippet: The appointment of Ron Klain, a White House veteran, spoke of the seriousness of the situation for the administration, which hoped to put the management of the crisis back on track.

byline.contributor: Sabrina Tavernise reported from Washington, and Mitch Smith from Akron, Ohio. Reporting was contributed by Michael Schmidt, Julie Hirschfeld Davis, Jonathan Martin and Michael D. Shear from Washington; Alan Blinder from Atlanta; and Manny Fernandez from Dallas.
byline.original: By SABRINA TAVERNISE and MITCH SMITH

docs.abstract: In his new book, “Being Mortal,” Dr. Atul Gawande acknowledges paying scant attention to end-of-life issues.
docs.snippet: In his new book, “Being Mortal,” Dr. Atul Gawande acknowledges paying scant attention to end-of-life issues.

docs.lead_paragraph: In a draft document, the World Health Organization has acknowledged that it botched attempts to stop the now-spiraling Ebola outbreak in West Africa, blaming factors including incompetent staff and a lack of information.

headline.main: UN: We Botched Response to the Ebola Outbreak
headline.print_headline: UN: We Botched Response to the Ebola Outbreak

docs.snippet: In a draft document, the World Health Organization has acknowledged that it botched attempts to stop the now-spiraling Ebola outbreak in West Africa, blaming factors including incompetent staff and a lack of information.

docs.lead_paragraph: As they did in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, health care workers treating Ebola are forced to learn a great deal in a short time.

headline.main: For Ebola Health Workers, Risks and Duty Collide
headline.print_headline: Out on the Front Lines, Risks and Duty Collide

docs.abstract: Health care workers treating Ebola are forced to learn a great deal in a short time, as they did in the early days of the AIDS epidemic; nurses' unions have been vocal in raising concerns and lead charge for better protection.
docs.snippet: As they did in the early days of the AIDS epidemic, health care workers treating Ebola are forced to learn a great deal in a short time.
